docs.lead_paragraph: In these wobbling economic times, it was only a question of when public officials would turn toward illegal immigrants and ask how much of a burden they pose to taxpayers. Nowhere is the question more sensitive than in Los Angeles County, where an estimated 1.1 million illegal immigrants reside. Even so, with the state's budget shortfall calculated at as much as $38 billion in the next 13 months and the county's at more than $400 million, it had to come.

headline.main: Los Angeles County Weighs Cost of Illegal Immigration

docs.abstract: Los Angeles County Supervisors Board, 3-2, defeats Supervisor Michael D Antonovich's proposal to require illegal immigrants to get work permits and their employers to post bonds to pay for their health care costs; Antonovich holds proposal is not attack on immigrants, but effort to address high cost of providing health care to indigent workers; estimated 1.1 million illegal aliens live in county (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: For seven years, Awilda Vazquez was treading water on welfare, struggling to raise her two daughters, but then she got her big chance, landing a job as a $30,000-a-year clerk in the New York Fire Department. But Ms. Vazquez, of Red Hook, Brooklyn, worries that she will soon land back on the welfare rolls because she was one of the 2,000 people who were laid off on Friday as Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg sought to cut the city's $3.8 billion budget deficit.

headline.main: From Work To Welfare Reversal Seen In City Layoffs

docs.abstract: One of 2,000 New York City workers laid off in budget crunch is Awilda Vazquez, who struggled off welfare rolls and landed $30,000 clerk job with Fire Department; photo; District Council 37 questions how much city will save if workers like Vazquez go back on public assistance (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Doctors and their supporters held demonstrations across New York State yesterday, calling for state and federal legislation to limit lawsuit awards that they contend are driving up health care costs. The drive to limit civil jury verdicts is an evergreen issue in Albany and Washington, perennially stalled by Democratic lawmakers and their close allies, the trial lawyers. While there has been no sign of change in the State Capitol, doctors and their allies have been heartened by movement on legislation, backed by President Bush, in the Republican-controlled Congress.

headline.main: Few Doctors At Protests On Insurance In New York

docs.abstract: Doctors hold rallies around New York to call for legiislation to limit lawsuit awards they say drive up health care costs; photo (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Allstate insurance agents have scored a significant victory over their company in a long and closely watched battle over age discrimination, legal experts said yesterday. In an order issued late last week in Philadelphia, a federal judge tentatively agreed to certify the agents' lawsuit as a class action, sharply raising the stakes in the case and the pressure on Allstate to begin negotiations toward a settlement, the legal experts said.

headline.main: Legal Experts Say Allstate Lost a Battle In Agents' Suit

docs.abstract: Allstate insurance agents score significant victory over company in battle over age discrimination; Federal Judge John P Fullam agres to certify agents' lawsuit as class action, sharply raising stakes in case and pressure on Allstate to begin negotiations toward settlement; case court represent more than 6,000 Allstate agents and be one of largest accusing company of age discrimination if certified as class-action lawsuit; lawsuit by agents and Equal Employment Opportunity Commission grew out of decision by Allstate in late 1999 to streamline its sales force; company dismissed more than 6,000 agents from team of 15,200 following summer; some agents complained to EEOC that more than 90 percent of dismissed agents were over 40 and that their average age was 50 (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: As Congress begins drafting Medicare legislation, one of the most contentious and politically explosive issues is whether the same drug benefits should be available to all. The Bush administration and many of its allies on Capitol Hill say they want to use prescription drug benefits as an incentive to encourage older Americans to enroll in private health plans. People who stay with the traditional, government-run Medicare program would receive only modest drug benefits, while those who join private plans would be rewarded with much more extensive coverage.

headline.main: Bush Drug Proposal in Medicare Plan Faces Stiff Battle

docs.abstract: Bush administration and many of its Congressional allies want to offer only modest outpatient drug benefits to people who stay with traditional, government-run Medicare program, while rewarding those who join private plans with much more extensive coverage; say private plans would be more efficient than Medicare's lumbering bureaucracy; most Democrats and many Republicans oppose proposal; Congressional leaders hope to approve Medicare bill by fall; photo (M)
docs.snippet: As Congress begins drafting Medicare legislation, one of the most contentious and politically explosive issues is whether the same drug benefits should be available to all.    The Bush administration and many of its allies on Capitol Hill say they...

byline.original: By ROBERT PEAR and ROBIN TONER

docs.lead_paragraph: Black women die of breast cancer at higher rates than white women with comparable tumors, but the gap disappears among women old enough to qualify for Medicare, according to a study released yesterday. The study's authors suggested that the findings indicated that access to treatment rather than differences in biology probably played a bigger role in the higher death rate for black women than previous research had found. The study also found that later-stage breast cancer was more likely to be diagnosed in black women of all ages, leading the researchers to call for greater efforts to increase screening and follow-up. For the study, which will be published in the June issue of the journal Cancer, the researchers analyzed data collected on more than 110,000 breast cancer cases in 11 states and cities over seven years.
docs.abstract: National Cancer Institute researcher Dr Kenneth C Chu publishes study in journal Cancer that finds disparity in breast cancer death rate between white women and black women may be attributable to health care availability; gap in recovery rate disappeared in women over 65, presumably because they qualify for medicare (S)
docs.snippet: Black women die of breast cancer at higher rates than white women with comparable tumors, but the gap disappears among women old enough to qualify for Medicare, according to a study released yesterday.   The study's authors suggested that the...

docs.lead_paragraph: As he travels incessantly around New Jersey, Gov. James E. McGreevey often talks like a man on a victory tour. He delights in telling audiences about his grand ambitions for New Jersey and the tough decisions he has made: revamping the Department of Motor Vehicles, reorganizing the state university system, enacting tough environmental regulations, fighting suburban sprawl, starting a literacy program. All of it, Mr. McGreevey invariably points out, accomplished while closing a mammoth budget deficit.

headline.main: McGreevey's Miscues Feed Criticism of His Leadership

docs.abstract: New Jersey Gov James E McGreevey is being criticized even by fellow Democrats for political fiascos that have raised questions about his judgment; he is frequently having to respond to headlines reporting on his taking junkets and personal helicopter trips at taxpayer expense, advocating pet projects and appointments for political patrons, or making succession of high-profile nominations that have turned into public relations disasters; frustration at state's fiscal problems has added to his woes; McGreevey acknowledges that he has occasionally stumbled, but remains resolutely unfazed by criticism and recent polls showing his approval ratings in 30's and low 40's; insists his ratings will rebound with economy; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: In a marathon day of referendums, Swiss voters agreed on Sunday to modernize their armed forces, overhaul the country's civil defense and keep nuclear energy. They turned down proposals for four car-free Sundays a year, universal disabled access to public buildings, changes in health insurance financing, tenants' rights and more apprenticeship places.

headline.main: In a Busy Day At the Polls, Swiss Decide Nine Issues

docs.abstract: Swiss voters consider nine separate referendums on single day; under Switzerland's system of direct democracy, 100,000 signatures on petition can force national vote on amending Constitution, and 50,000 signatures can challenge proposed government laws; country's 4.7 million voters are summoned to polls three or four times a year; opinion polls before latest vote indicate that majority of those questioned could not name single subject on ballot; voter turnout is 48.3 percent (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: General Electric's largest union, which staged a two-day walkout over health benefits in January, threatened to go on strike again next month as it began negotiations yesterday for a new contract covering 14,000 workers. With General Electric pushing to increase employee contributions toward health coverage, union leaders said they might call a strike if G.E., one of the world's most profitable companies, pressed too hard on the issue.

headline.main: G.E. Union Warns of Strike Over Health Care Increases

docs.abstract: International Union of Electronic Workers-CWA, General Electric's largest union, begins talks on new contract with threat of strike over company's push to increase worker contributions toward health coverage; health care costs are key issue in labor negotiations nationwide (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: When doctors decide which drugs to prescribe, the most important criterion is often not how well they work, their side effects or their prices. Instead, doctors are most likely to prescribe a pill if they think that a managed care program will pay for it, according to surveys by several drug companies. The drug has to be on what is called ''the formulary,'' a list that managed care groups approve.

headline.kicker: THE SUPREME COURT: THE DRUG MAKERS

docs.abstract: Surveys find that key consideration of doctors in prescribing particular medication is often knowledge that drug is on managed care programs' formulary or list, which is why Supreme Court decision allowing Maine to try to lower drug prices is seen as setback for drug industry; Maine would use Medicaid's buying power to negotiate bulk discounts, which companies fear would lead to govenrnment-sponsored formulary, and lower profits (S)
